body_text.text: The recent sequencing of the genomes of many closely related species has created a powerful new paradigm for investigating the evolutionary processes that generate the diversity of life on Earth.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Comparing the complete human genome sequence to that of a chimpanzee, our closest living relative, Dreszer et al. (2007) demonstrated that the most divergent regions of both genomes show a striking W/S substitution bias and that this association is correlated with recombination rates.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This bias in divergent sequences (BDS) is not limited to neutrally evolving sequences and can significantly impact substitution patterns in conserved noncoding sequences (Pollard, Salama, King et al. 2006) and proteincoding exons (Berglund et al. 2009;Ratnakumar et al. 2010), suggesting the possibility of significant functional consequences.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These observations have profound implications regarding the interpretation of adaptive evolution in fast-evolving sequences of the human genome and our understanding of the evolutionary forces driving divergence between closely related species in general.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this paper, we explore two fundamental questions about BDS and what the phenomenon tells us about genome evolution and function.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: First, is BDS unique to the hominoids or a more widespread phenomenon?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The recent sequencing of many closely related eukaryotic species enables us to investigate the phylogenetic extent of BDS.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Second, what evolutionary processes produce BDS?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Based on the patterns of BDS found in human, Dreszer et al. (2007) argued that GC-based gene conversion (gBGC) (Duret and Galtier 2009) is the cause of BDS.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: gBGC is a nonadaptive evolutionary process that favors the fixation of ª The Author(s) 2011.

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: weak alleles near the double-strand breaks that initiate recombination events.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Episodes of gBGC in a genomic region could produce an association between W/S substitutions and substitution density (BDS) by driving W/S mutations to fixation in recombination hotspots.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We investigate the origin of BDS by examining correlations between BDS and genomic variables, including recombination rates, in different species.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To examine BDS in a broader phylogenetic context, we characterized recent substitutions in eight trios of eukaryotic organisms including: human (Homo sapiens), mouse (Mus musculus), dog (Canis familiaris), chicken (Gallus gallus), stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus), fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster), worm (Caenorhabditis elegans), and yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We selected these species based on availability of sequenced genomes for a closely related comparison taxon and an outgroup, quality of the genome assemblies, and (if possible) availability of recombination maps.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To enable these genome-wide analyses, we inferred substitution histories using maximum likelihood and a contextdependent model of evolution with the PHAST package (Hubisz et al. 2011).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This approach accounts directly for CpG hypermutability and other context effects that can lead to incorrect inference of substitution type (e.g., W/S vs. not W/S) in parsimony-based analyses.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Next, we analyzed substitution patterns using a new efficient statistical test for the association of nucleotide substitution types with substitution rates and genome annotations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Most previous studies of substitution patterns in divergent regions have focused on discrete predefined elements across the genome; in contrast, our approach is more broad and allows a flexible continuous definition of ''divergent'' based on the density of substitution across the genome.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our work extends the approach of Dreszer et al. (2007) and provides a more rigorous statistical framework for measuring associations between substitution type and density.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Using these tools, we confirm the previously observed pattern of BDS in the human genome and its association with elevated recombination rates.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our analysis of nonprimate clades shows that BDS is common outside of human, though not universal.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: When BDS is present, it exists in both coding and noncoding sequence and is often, but not always, correlated with high rates of recombination.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This correlation, paired with the lack of W/S bias in within-species polymorphisms, argues that a recombination-driven fixation bias for strong nucleotides, such as that produced by gBGC, may be involved in the production of BDS, especially when there is variation in strength and location of gBGC over time.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Overall, the strong evidence we find for BDS in many eukaryote genomes highlights the importance of understanding its causes and developing statistical models of DNA and protein evolution that incorporate these observations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: Conservation scores for each reference species were downloaded from the Genome Browser; phyloP (Pollard et al. 2010) scores were used when available, otherwise phastCons (Siepel et al. 2005; Hubisz et al. 2011) scores were used.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: For human, we used the combined recombination map from the HapMap project (The International Hapmap Consortium 2007), as well as the deCODE genetics male and female maps which are based on 15,257 Icelandic parent-offspring pairs (Kong et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: Mouse recombination data were downloaded from the Mouse Map Converter (Jackson Laboratories 2009), which is based on SNP analysis across 46 families (Shifman et al. 2006;Cox et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Data

body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: For fruit fly, the Drosophila Recombination Rate Calculator (Fiston-Lavier et al. 2010), which compares genetic and physical maps of the genome to infer recombination rates, was used.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: Our BDS analysis pipeline consists of several steps.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: For each clade of interest, we started with an alignment of three species: reference, comparison (sister taxon), and outgroup.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Our analysis workflow is as follows (details below).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: First, the three-species alignments were filtered for alignment quality.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Then substitution histories were computed using maximum likelihood and a context-dependent evolutionary model.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Given the set of expected recent substitutions, the association between patterns of substitution and substitution density (BDS) was quantified.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Finally, the strength of the BDS across the genome was correlated with several other genomic features.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Data processing and analysis were performed using custom programs written in R (R Development Core Team 2009) and Python with SciPy (Jones et al. 2001) and matplotlib (Hunter 2007).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Alignment Filtering.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: In order to study patterns of substitution between species, it is crucial that the data are not polluted by false substitutions introduced by alignment errors.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: We filtered all alignments in a consistent manner across each set of species using several criteria that could be applied in each clade considered.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: First, repetitive sequences as identified by the UCSC Genome Browser alignment pipeline were not considered.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: These regions were identified using the Tandem Repeats Finder and RepeatMasker (Smit andHubley 2008-2010) and are indicated by lowercase letters in the alignments.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: (See the Genome Browser documentation for more details.)
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Next, the quality of the alignment around each position was considered.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: If there were any insertions or deletions between the reference and comparison species within five base pairs (bp) of a position, then it was not considered.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Finally, all positions in regions of the genome that had significant homology to another region of the genome were filtered out.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: These duplicated or repetitive regions are often difficult to align to other species due to their similarity.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: These regions were removed using the Genome Browser's chainSelf track of significant alignments of a genome with itself.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Identification of Recent Substitutions.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: We are interested in substitutions that occurred in the reference species since its divergence from the last common ancestor with the comparison species-for example, on the human lineage after its last common ancestor with chimpanzee.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: These branches of interest are indicated in red in figure 1.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: After filtering the alignments as described above, we fit a contextdependent dinucleotide phylogenetic model to the alignments for each chromosome using maximum likelihood.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: We used the general unrestricted dinucleotide model with strand symmetry (U2S) (Siepel and Haussler 2004).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: This phylogenetic model was fit to the alignments with phyloFit from the PHAST software package (Hubisz et al. 2011).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Using the model, we computed (also using phyloFit) the posterior expected number of substitutions of eachtypeon each branch of the tree for each site in the alignment.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Calculation of BDS.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Given the inferred probabilities of each type of substitution on the branch of interest at each site across each genome, we quantified the BDS with a log odds ratio that relates the density and pattern of substitutions across a genomic region.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: The odds ratio is based on a two-by-two contingency table in which each possible substitution was classified as
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: 1) W/S or not W/S and
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: 2) in a divergent sequence or not.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Any substitution from an A or T in the ancestor to G or C in the reference species was W/S, and all others were not.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Each position was classified as divergent/not divergent based on the substitution density in a genomic window of a given size around it.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: The expected number of substitutions of each type on the reference branch at this position was then added to the relevant cell of the contingency table.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Given the resulting two-by-two contingency table for a genomic region of interest, we calculated the log odds ratio and associated statistics in the standard manner after rounding the expected number of substitutions in each cell to the nearest whole number.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: This log odds ratio quantifies the strength of association between W/S bias and sequence divergence.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: If substitutions in divergent windows exhibit an excess of W/S changes, then the log odds ratio is greater than zero.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: It is less than zero if these divergent regions contain fewer W/S substitutions than expected.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: We refer to this log odds ratio as the BDS score and use the terms ''bias,'' ''BDS,'' and ''W/S BDS'' to refer to increased W/S substitution in regions of high divergence.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: The genomic regions over which the BDS score was calculated may be small sequence blocks (as used in the correlation analysis), a set of regions across the genome (as in the coding sequence analysis), or the entire genome.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: The significance of the BDS score was assessed with Fisher's exact test (FET).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: All reported P values are from the FET unless otherwise indicated.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: We explored a range of window sizes and density cutoffs; figure 2 demonstrates the robustness of our results to any specific cutoff.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: When a single cutoff was required, we used window size of 1,000 bp and a substitution density such that as near to 5% of all substitutions as possible were assigned to the divergent group.
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: Because the referencecomparison species pairs we examined have different levels of sequence divergence, this threshold varies in absolute value across species (i.e., it is lower for species that are less diverged and higher for species that are more diverged).
body_text.section: Analysis

body_text.text: To explore the correlation of data that vary across the genome, we selected an appropriate block size on which the features could be quantified.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: (This was often limited by the scale of the recombination maps available or the number of expected substitutions in a region.)
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: Nonoverlapping blocks of 1 Mb were used for all species except for fly, worm, and yeast, where we used blocks of 10 and 100 kb due to their smaller genomes.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: We created a vector for each feature being compared, for example, BDS and recombination rate, across each corresponding block of the genome and calculated the Spearman rank correlation across all blocks.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: We also calculated and plotted the Spearman correlation of smoothed versions of the data.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: The data were smoothed by convolution with a seven-block Hanning window.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: To evaluate the significance of the difference in the correlation of a genomic feature with two other features, for example, in the comparison of BDS with male and female recombination rate, empirical P values were obtained by bootstrapping with 10,000 comparisons to random features.
body_text.section: Correlation of Genomic Features across the Genome.

body_text.text: We calculated BDS scores and P values for eight diverse eukaryotic lineages ( fig. 1).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: Figure 2A gives the BDS computed over substitutions on the human lineage since divergence from its last common ancestor with chimp for a range of window sizes and substitution density thresholds.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: For each window size, there is significant BDS; that is, the fastestevolving regions show a significant enrichment for W/S nucleotide substitutions (increasing curves; all P % 0).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: This result is in agreement with that reported in Dreszer et al. (2007) using parsimony to infer substitutions and a different statistical test for association between substitution type and density.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: Extending the analysis to other lineages, we find significant BDS in mouse (P 5 5.2 Â 10 À5 ), dog (P % 0), stickleback (P % 0), fruit fly (P % 0), and worm (P 5 5.1 Â 10 À5 ) ( fig. 1 and table 1).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: As in the human genome, the patterns of BDS in these species are not sensitive to the particular window size and density thresholds used ( fig. 2 and supplementary fig S1, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: However, we do observe interspecies differences in the magnitude of the BDS score.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: Dog exhibits the strongest bias, whereas mouse has the weakest statistically significant W/S BDS.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: Reversing the roles of the reference and comparison species, we also find BDS in chimpanzee and several additional genomes (data not shown).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: However, inference of substitution histories is more difficult in comparison species, whose genome assemblies tend to be lower quality and often lack the resources for proper alignment quality filtering.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: We also calculated a variation of the BDS score that considers only W/S and S/W substitutions.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: This resulted in slightly elevated scores compared with considering all substitution types.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: For example, in human, the bias increased from 0.12 to 0.14.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Vertebrates and Invertebrates

body_text.text: We do not observe W/S BDS in either chicken or yeast (table 1).
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: In contrast to the other vertebrates analyzed, chicken shows a small but significant strong-to-weak (S/W) bias in fast-evolving regions (P 5 5.3 Â 10 À6 ).
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: Similarly, yeast shows a significant excess of S/W nucleotide changes in divergent regions (P55:8Â10 À7 , fig. 2D).
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: This pattern in fixed substitutions is consistent with the S/W mutation bias observed in yeast (Lynch et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: In the next sections, we investigate several aspects of BDS that help us to interpret these observations.
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: We consider possible explanations in the Discussion.
body_text.section: Chicken and Yeast Show a Significant Lack of W/S BDS

body_text.text: The species trios analyzed exhibit a range of evolutionary distances between the reference and comparison species ( fig. 1; table 1).
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: It is possible that the length of the branch considered might affect
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: 1) our power to detect BDS and
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: 2) the estimated strength of the BDS between the two species compared.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: Several observations argue against such biases, however.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: First, significant BDS patterns were observed in all comparisons.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: Hence, even though branch length likely influences the test's power, we are still able to detect a signal in each lineage.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: Additionally, the strength of the BDS observed between two species is not well correlated with their divergence (table 1).
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: We also calculated BDS in substitutions between human and a series of increasingly divergent species that mirror the divergences of the other eukaryotic species sets considered here.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: In three of the four comparisons (human with tarsier, tree shrew, and opossum), significant bias was still identifiable between human and the more distant comparison species (supplementary table S1, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: However, the fact that W/S BDS was not found in one of the comparisons (human with marmoset) suggests that the sources of BDS may not be constant over time or that our ability to detect BDS depends upon the quality of the comparison genome.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: We also tested the use of increasingly divergent outgroup species and found no major influence on patterns of BDS.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: Thus, our method is able to detect bias within the range of divergence found in the species sets we analyzed, including those used to quantify BDS in chicken and yeast.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: We therefore conclude that factors other than evolutionary distance appear to drive the variation in BDS between lineages.
body_text.section: Variation in BDS between Species Is Not Due to Their Divergence

body_text.text: Coding and noncoding sequences are often under very different patterns of evolutionary constraint.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: The proteincoding fractions of the genomes we considered vary from around 2% in human to 73% in yeast (table 2).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Thus, if substitution bias is different in coding and noncoding regions, this could influence our conclusions about the phylogenetic   FIG. 2.-Divergent sequences are significantly W/S biased in many, but not all, eukaryotes.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Genomic regions with a high divergence show a significant enrichment for W/S substitutions (BDS) compared with regions with fewer substitutions.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: BDS is found in human (A), mouse, dog (B), stickleback, fly, and worm (C).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: In contrast, chicken and yeast (D) do not exhibit significant W/S BDS.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: These patterns are not sensitive to the size of the window (500-2000 bp) or the substitution density threshold.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: The gray bars indicate 95% confidence intervals for the BDS score.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: This figure includes substitution densities for which between 1% and 99% of substitutions are considered divergent.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Table 1 gives BDS statistics for all species considered, and plots are provided for the other four species in supplementary figure S1 (Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: distribution of BDS.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: In particular, if BDS was absent or very weak in coding regions, we would have less power to detect genome-wide BDS in species with a high fraction of coding DNA, such as worm and yeast.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: To investigate this issue, we calculated BDS scores separately for coding regions in each species.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Table 2 demonstrates that in species with significant genome-wide BDS, significant bias is present in coding sequence considered alone.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Interestingly, coding regions generally exhibit stronger BDS than noncoding sequence.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: Similarly, coding sequence in yeast and chicken show S/W BDS, in agreement with the genome-wide evidence of S/W BDS in these species.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: The S/W bias in chicken coding regions is of similar magnitude to the genome-wide amount, but is not significant.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: This is not surprising given the weak signal in chicken genome wide.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: These results argue that patterns of bias in coding and noncoding sequences are usually in agreement and that the different fraction of coding sequence in different genomes is unlikely to be the source of their different bias patterns.
body_text.section: BDS Occurs in Both Coding and Noncoding Regions

body_text.text: In the previous sections, a single BDS score was computed for each species to quantify genome-wide patterns of bias.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: To profile variation in BDS within genomes, we computed BDS scores across the chromosomes of each species in windows ranging in length from 10 kb to 1 Mb.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: The strength of BDS varies across the chromosomes of each species (fig. 3).
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: Some sections of the chromosome have significant bias, whereas others do not exhibit any BDS.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: This variation was observed previously in human (Dreszer et al. 2007), where a significant increase in BDS was found near the telomeres of most human and chimp chromosomes.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: Although variance in the BDS score is universal, increased BDS near telomeres is not a general phenomenon in all species we considered.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: BDS strength also varies between chromosomes.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: To compare the bias between chromosomes, we computed the BDS score for each chromosome in each species.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: In human, all chromosomes show peaks of significant BDS, but there is significant variation in the strength of the bias overall on different chromosomes (P , 2.2 Â 10 À16 ., Woolf test).
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: The overall GC content of a chromosome is strongly correlated with recombination rate and negatively correlated with chromosome length in many species, including human (Fullerton et al. 2001) and chicken (International Chicken Genome Sequencing Consortium 2004).
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: To frame BDS patterns in the context of these previous findings, we correlated its strength on each human chromosome with these features.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: Chromosomal BDS was not significantly correlated with the chromosome's GC content (Spearman q50:04), recombination rate (q5 À 0:01), or length (q50:04).
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: A similar lack of correlation of chromosomal BDS with GC content, recombination rate, and length was observed in all other species with significant BDS.
body_text.section: Intraspecies BDS Varies within and between Chromosomes

body_text.text: To investigate patterns of BDS at a finer scale, we calculated Spearman rank correlations of BDS in 1 Mb blocks with several genome features that vary across chromosomes: sex-averaged recombination rate, evolutionary conservation, NOTE.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: -BDS is a log odds ratio quantifying the association between W/S substitution and the density of substitution.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: P values are computed using FET.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: Branch lengths are given in expected substitutions per site.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: All statistics are based on a cluster size of 1,000 bp and a density threshold that results in approximately 5% of substitutions being placed in the divergent class.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: GC content, and substitution rate (table 3).
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: Stickleback, worm, and yeast were not included in the recombination correlation analysis due to lack of appropriate recombination maps.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: Our findings support the previous result in human, obtained using different methods, that recombination rate and BDS are correlated (Dreszer et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: This pattern occurs in other species as well; three of the four species (human, mouse, and fly) that have significant genome-wide BDS and recombination rate data show a significant correlation between these variables.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: The one exception is dog, which has experienced a recent pseudogenization of the PRDM9 gene (Oliver et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: This loss may explain the strong BDS in dog and the lack of correlation between BDS and recombination (see Discussion).
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: BDS is not consistently   FIG. 3.-BDS is often correlated with recombination rate.

body_text.text: The BDS varies in strength along chromosomes and is significantly correlated with sexaveraged recombination rate in (A) human chromosome 6 (q50:36 smoothed, P 5 9 Â 10 À7 ) and (B) mouse chromosome 16 (q50:36 smoothed, P 5 2 Â 10 À4 ).
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: The smoothed data are plotted with solid lines, and the raw values are indicated with dashed lines.

body_text.text: For ease of visualization and comparison in this figure, the data have been scaled so that the minimum value is 0 and the maximum is 1.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: correlated with GC content, substitution density, or conservation, although specific species do show modest significant correlations with some of these variables.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: Most notably, three out of the six species with genome-wide BDS have a positive correlation between BDS and evolutionary sequence conservation.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: Overall, our analyses suggest that BDS and recombination rate are often but not always correlated.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: It also appears that fluctuations in BDS are not directly associated with GC percent, divergence, or conservation; however, factors that indirectly influence these features may be relevant to the production of BDS patterns in some species.
body_text.section: Local BDS Is Often Correlated with Recombination Rate

body_text.text: In the species for which we have sex-specific recombination data, we also considered the correlation of these rates with BDS separately for the two sexes.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: Previous studies of human Alu repeats (Webster et al. 2005) and substitution hotspots (Dreszer et al. 2007) indicate that biases associated with recombination may have a sex-specific impact.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: We find that BDS in human and mouse is more strongly associated with male recombination rate than with female (q50:152 vs. 0:119 in human, P % 0:042; q50:093 vs. 0:014 in mouse, P % 0:001).
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: In dog, BDS does not show a significant correlation with sex-averaged recombination rate.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: However, when looking at male and female rates separately, the correlation with the male rate is significantly greater than with female (q50:058 vs. À0:039, P % 0:001), and though it is small in magnitude, the correlation between male recombination rate and BDS is significant (P 5 0.018).
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: In contrast, when looking sex-specific rates in chicken, a species that does not show significant BDS overall, neither male or female recombination rates are significantly associated with BDS across the genome (q5 À 0:079 and À0:074, respectively), and the difference between the sex-specific correlations is not significant.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: These results suggest that when significant genome-wide BDS is present, the spatial correlation of BDS and recombination along a species' chromosomes is consistently higher in males.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: Sex-specific recombination data from additional species would help to test and further explore this hypothesis.
body_text.section: BDS and Recombination Are More Strongly Correlated in Males

body_text.text: Our test can also be applied to SNP data to study bias in population-level sequence variation.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: Dreszer et al. (2007) found no W/S bias in regions of the human with a high density of SNPs, suggesting that a fixation bias rather than a mutation bias was likely responsible for the BDS.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: To explore the phylogenetic extent of this pattern, we considered SNPs in human, mouse, and chicken.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: SNPs for each species were downloaded from the UCSC Table Browser  (Karolchik et al. 2004).
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: The ancestral variant was identified by parsimony using the alignment with the comparison species.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: Then, BDS scores were computed for SNPs using the same methods as used for fixed differences.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: SNPs for which no comparison species was present or with indeterminate ancestry were not considered in the analysis.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: SNPs in human, mouse, and chicken do not exhibit W/S BDS (supplementary fig. S4, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: This contrasts with the patterns in recent fixed substitutions in human and mouse.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: In fact, there is a significant lack of W/S changes in regions with the highest SNP density; the BDS scores are À0:095 for human SNPs (P % 0), À0:018 for mouse (P 5 3.3 Â 10 À5 ), and À0:177 for chicken (P 5 8.5 Â 10 À6 ).
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: Thus, just as the BDS in recent fixed substitutions is present in species other than human, the previously observed lack of BDS in human SNPs also appears to be a general pattern.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: This result suggests that BDS is unlikely to be driven by local variation in mutation rates and patterns.
body_text.section: BDS Is Not Present in SNPs

body_text.text: The use of parsimony to infer substitution types can potentially introduce biases into analyses of substitution patterns (Eyre-Walker 1998; Hernandez et al. 2007).
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: CpG hypermutability, which increases the probability of multiple substitutions at a site and depends on the dinucleotide context, is a particular concern.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: To avoid these possible biases, our results are based on genome-wide substitution histories reconstructed in a maximum likelihood framework using a context-dependent evolutionary model.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: For comparison, we also performed the analysis using
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: 1) maximum likelihood with a noncontext-dependent strand-specific reversible model (SSREV) and
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: 2) parsimony.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: Using maximum likelihood with the SSREV model produces very similar conclusions to those obtained with the U2S context-dependent model (supplementary fig. S2, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: This suggests that context- -Each value is the Spearman correlation of BDS with the specified feature across blocks of the genome.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: Bold indicates a significant correlation at the 0.01 level.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: Blocks of 1 Mb were used for all species, except for fly (100 kb), worm (10 kb), and yeast (10 kb).
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: The raw values for each feature were used; the correlation coefficients generally increase if the data are smoothed before calculation (e.g., see fig. 3).
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: dependent effects, such as CpG hypermutability, do influence the results slightly, but not significantly.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: The use of parsimony also leads to qualitatively similar conclusions; however, worm and chicken change their BDS classification (supplementary fig. S3, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: When comparing all three methods, the two maximum likelihood approaches agree most closely, suggesting that using parsimony may indeed have an impact on inferred substitution histories.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: This is likely the result of fairly long branches in several of the clades considered; these are more likely to have experienced multiple substitutions, which would be missed by parsimony.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: Within the maximum likelihood context, our results are robust to the use of a context-dependent model or not, indicating that CpG effects are not the driving force behind BDS.
body_text.section: BDS Patterns Are Robust to the Methodology Used to Infer Substitution Histories

body_text.text: We have demonstrated that divergent regions of several metazoan genomes from human to worm are associated with elevated rates of W/S substitution relative to the rest of the genome.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In contrast, chicken and yeast do not exhibit significant BDS.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In human and several other species with significant BDS, we found consistent BDS in coding as well as noncoding sequences, correlations between BDS scores and recombination rates (especially in the male sex), and no significant BDS in SNPs.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: All of these observations are consistent with a recombination-associated, nonadaptive fixation bias as a cause of BDS.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: gBGC is a likely candidate.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: This bias occurs when there is a weak-strong polymorphism in a recombination heteroduplex, and the DNA mismatch is preferentially repaired to the strong base pair.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: These GC-biased conversion blocks are thought to range between 200 bp and 2 kb in length (Duret and Galtier 2009).
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: gBGC has been directly observed in yeast (Mancera et al. 2008), but obtaining experimental evidence for the action of gBGC is extremely challenging in other species.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: Nonetheless, gBGC has received considerable attention as a possible explanation for many dominant and unexplained genomic attributes, such as the large-scale variation in GC content (the so-called isochore structure) of mammalian genomes (Eyre-Walker and Hurst 2001;Galtier et al. 2001;Meunier and Duret 2004;Romiguier et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: By driving strong alleles to higher frequencies and ultimately to fixation around recombination hotspots, bursts of gBGC could result in an increase in substitution rates and a W/S-biased substitution pattern (Berglund et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: These evolutionary events could produce the BDS pattern.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: Other evolutionary mechanisms, such as variation in mutation rates across the genome or natural selection for GC alleles (Eyre-Walker and Hurst 2001), could also produce BDS.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: However, the action of a biased mutation rate is not consistent with our observations.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: Specifically, the lack of W/S BDS in SNPs argues against mutation bias as a source of the BDS pattern.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: The relationship between BDS and selection is less clear.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: If natural selection on GC content drives BDS, we would expect consistent differences in bias between regions of high and low conservation, such as coding and noncoding sequence.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: In most of the taxa we examined, significant BDS is present in both coding and noncoding sequence, and higher in coding regions.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: In addition, three species (mouse, dog, and fly) show a significant correlation between genome-wide patterns of BDS and evolutionary conservation.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: But the three other species with significant BDS (human, stickleback, and worm) show no such correlation.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: If selection has a role in BDS, we might additionally expect BDS to be stronger in species with large effective population sizes due to the increased efficiency of selection; however, this pattern is not observed.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: Thus, selective forces may be involved in the creation of BDS in some lineages, perhaps in concert with gBGC, but they are unlikely to be the sole cause of BDS.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: Together, these results suggest that there may multiple causes and paths to the creation of BDS in genomes.
body_text.section: Episodic Biased Gene Conversion Is a Likely Cause of BDS

body_text.text: A recent study of the evolution of GC content across the mammalian phylogeny suggests that its dynamics are not constant across the tree and are influenced by many factors related to life history and genome organization (Romiguier et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The variation we observe in BDS strength across the taxa considered here suggests a similarly dynamic picture for BDS with many possible factors influencing its strength.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: For example, the phylogenetic extent of gBGC, a likely source of BDS, across eukaryotes and its effect on genome evolution are currently unknown.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: There is strong sequence-based evidence for gBGC in mammals (Duret and Galtier 2009), and a recent comprehensive analysis of meiosis products in yeast provided direct experimental evidence of gBGC (Mancera et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: There is also indirect evidence of gBGC in additional eukaryotic taxa, based on correlations between GC content and recombination rate or chromosome size found in birds (International Chicken Genome Sequencing Consortium 2004), turtles (Kuraku et al. 2006), flies (Marais et al. 2003), worms (Marais et al. 2001), and several other species (Glé min 2010).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: If gBGC is a cause of BDS, our identification of BDS in several eukaryotic species adds to the mounting evidence for its importance in genome evolution.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: However, it also suggests that population characteristics and mating patterns can influence the strength of BDS.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Generation time, effective population size, frequency of outcrossing, recombination pattern, and conversion bias will all influence the effectiveness of gBGC (Duret and Arndt 2008), and many of these traits vary between species or within species over evolutionary time.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: These factors complicate cross-species comparison.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: For example, in light of the experimental evidence for gBGC in S. cerevisiae (Birdsell 2002;Mancera et al. 2008), our finding of a significant lack of W/S BDS in yeast might seem to argue against gBGC as a cause of the bias.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: However, yeast differs from the other species we analyzed in a number of relevant genetic and physiological dimensions.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Several aspects of sensu stricto yeast biology could act to limit gBGC's mutagenic impact.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Most wild yeasts studied to date have very low frequencies of sex and outcrossing; recent work estimates that S. paradoxus undergoes meiosis only once in every 1,000 generations and only 1% of matings are outcrossed (Tsai et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Since gBGC requires both meiosis and heterozygosity, its effect may be reduced in yeast by a factor of approximately 10 5 compared with obligately outcrossed species (Marais et al. 2004;Glé min et al. 2006;Tsai et al. 2010;Harrison and Charlesworth 2011).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The resulting reduced mutagenic impact of gBGC has been proposed as an explanation for several differences in genomic patterns between yeast and other eukaryotes, such as the conservation of recombination hotspots (Tsai et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Thus, the lack of detectable BDS in yeast is not inconsistent with the theory that gBGC is involved in creating BDS in other species.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Several factors may contribute to the lower BDS observed in mouse than in human.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: For example, recombination rate is thought to be approximately two times higher on average in human than in mouse (Coop and Przeworski 2006), and it is also less variable across mouse chromosomes.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Since BDS likely results from episodic gBGC (either in time or across the chromosome), this relative lack of variation would produce less difference between divergent and nondivergent sequences in mouse.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: In agreement with this interpretation, a very recent study found that substitution patterns are under different influences in primates and rodents with a weaker effect of gBGC in rodents (Clé ment and Arndt 2011).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: In dog, in contrast to other species with BDS, BDS and recombination rate do not show a significant correlation across the genome.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The PRDM9 gene, which is thought to determine the location of about 40% of human recombination hotspots, has been pseudogenized in dog (Oliver et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: This event likely dramatically influenced the recombination landscape of dog and thus may explain why current recombination patterns do not correlate well with historical patterns of bias over the entire branch to the ancestor of dog and cat.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Further investigations are needed to determine exactly why BDS is so strong in the dog genome.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The chicken genome lacks significant W/S BDS despite an estimated recombination rate, on both macro-and microchromosomes, considerably higher than in human (International Chicken Genome Sequencing Consortium 2004).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: However, the chicken karyotype is thought to have been far more stable over time than that of most mammals and may resemble that of the ancestral amniote (Webster et al. 2006).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Lack of chromosomal rearrangements removes a common source of variation in recombination rate across the genome over time.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: In addition, the cellular machinery for determining recombination hotspots may be different in birds because sauropsids lack PRDM9 as well (Oliver et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Finally, the varying quality and availability of genome sequence data complicate cross-species comparisons of BDS.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Low-coverage genome sequences are more likely to create noise from false substitutions inferred from sequencing errors.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Our sequence and alignment quality filters help correct for these differences.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: But in the end, some subsets of each genome may still be influenced by error.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The phylogenetic patterns of BDS identified here point to the need for future work integrating all relevant variables in a consistent model for BDS.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: Unfortunately, this approach awaits further data generation as many of the important variables are not yet well-characterized across multiple taxa.
body_text.section: Why Is BDS Stronger in Some Species than Others?

body_text.text: The dramatic enrichment for W/S substitutions in and around human accelerated regions (HARs) (Pollard, Salama, King, et al. 2006;Katzman et al. 2010) and the presence of possibly deleterious BDS in coding sequence (Berglund et al. 2009;Ratnakumar et al. 2010) suggest a complex interaction between BDS, selection, and the evolution of functional DNA elements.
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: If the substitutions driving BDS in coding regions are caused by gBGC, they may increase the susceptibility of a gene to malfunction, as would be expected from the accumulation of mildly deleterious alleles (Charlesworth B and Charlesworth D 1998).
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: The presence of BDS in many HARs prompted the suggestion that gBGC, rather than positive selection, may have generated the acceleration (Galtier and Duret 2007).
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: Thus, we might expect that HARs showing strong evidence of gBGC would be less likely to have obtained new functions in human.
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: HAR1 and HAR2 (HACNS1), the two fastest evolving HARs, have strikingly biased substitution patterns.
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: However, there is strong experimental evidence of function maintenance in HAR1 (Pollard, Salama, Lambert, et al. 2006) and gain in HAR2 (Prabhakar et al. 2008)-a surprising result if the human-specific changes in these sequences were created by a purely neutral mutational process.
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: Therefore, we hypothesize that in some evolutionary scenarios, gBGC substitutions may themselves lead to novel functions or may set the stage for later adaptive changes, perhaps due to compensatory substitutions driven by selection.
body_text.section: gBGC and Selection may Jointly Shape the Evolution of Functional Sequences

body_text.text: In this study, we used efficient statistical methods to highlight phylogenetic patterns of a substitution bias.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Our analysis of BDS in many eukaryotes suggests that it is common outside of human.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Episodic gBGC driven by recombination is likely to play a major role in the production of BDS, but a number of evolutionary and organismal factors are likely to influence its occurrence.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: These conclusions underscore the importance of developing models of sequence evolution that incorporate the action of gBGC and other processes that interact with selection (Hurst 2009).
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Several promising preliminary steps have been made in the modeling of gBGC and selection (Duret and Arndt 2008;Berglund et al. 2009;Ratnakumar et al. 2010;Glé min 2010).
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: As more genomes are assembled and richer recombination and polymorphism data become available for multiple species, we will be able to develop a deeper understanding of the causes and effects of BDS across the tree of life.
